description: Inherited from Middle English amen, from Old English, from Ecclesiastical Latin āmēn, from Ancient Greek ἀμήν (amḗn), from Biblical Hebrew אָמֵן‎ (ʾāmēn, “certainly, verily”) (cognate with Arabic آمِينَ‎ (ʔāmīna), Classical Syriac ܐܡܝܢ‎ (ʾāmên)). In Old English, it was used only at the end of the Gospels. Elsewhere, it was translated as sōþlīċe! (“truly”, “indeed!”), swā hit is (“so it is”), and sīe! (“[so] be it!”).

entries.meaning: At the end of religious prayers: so be it.
In many Abrahamic religious texts and creeds: certainly, verily.
examples: Amen, amen, I say to thee, except a man be born again, he can not see the kingdom of God.

entries.meaning: A title of Christ; the Faithful One (especially with reference to Revelation 3:14)

verbs.description: amen (third-person singular simple present amens, present participle amening, simple past and past participle amened)

examples: Most of the church amened and applauded.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To say amen to; to ratify solemnly.
